awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Comets and the History of Volatile Matter During Planetary System Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
Comets are early Solar System objects, mostly unchanged from the time the Solar System was created. The orbits of comets trace them to the locations in the outer Solar System where they formed. The compositions of molecules released from a comet can be measured by looking at their spectral signals. Combining these compositions with the comet orbits allows scientists to learn what materials were present at different locations in the early Solar System. The investigators will measure the amounts of many molecules in comet spectra, including H2O, HDO, CH4, C2H2, C2H6, H2S, SO2, OCS, CO, H2CO, CH3OH, HCOOH, HCN, HNC, CH3CN, HC3N, NH2CHO, and NH3. They will use ground-based observatories such as the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility, the W. M. Keck Observatory, and the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array. The years of 2017-2019 provide an excellent opportunity to study Jupiter Family Comets - comets with smaller orbits for which little is known about their compositions. This research serves the national interest by advancing our knowledge of the materials that served as the building blocks of our Solar System. Shows at the Watson-King Planetarium, Towson University, and the University of Missouri, Saint Louis' new planetarium will feature this research. Students from St. Louis and Baltimore, including many minority students, will have the chance to see them. 

 
The Principal Investigators will use high-resolution molecular spectroscopy of comets to measure the compositions of volatiles released from their nuclei, and to test theories about the early formation of the Solar System. While the orbits of observed comets link them to their dynamical reservoir (the distant Oort cloud or closer Kuiper belt), the suite of detected molecules for an individual comet provides a "snapshot" of the volatile inventory at their location in the protoplanetary disk where these comets formed. The investigators will use ground-based near-infrared and radio observatories, including the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility, the W. M. Keck Observatory, and the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array. By combining the advantages of each wavelength domain, the investigators' goal is to measure the relative abundances among various molecular species, including H2O, HDO, CH4, C2H2, C2H6, H2S, SO2, OCS, CO, H2CO, CH3OH, HCOOH, HCN, HNC, CH3CN, HC3N, NH2CHO, and NH3. New observations are planned of Jupiter Family comets and Oort cloud comets. The 2017-2019 period brings the best opportunity for many years to study Jupiter Family comets - a dynamical class underrepresented in compositional studies of all parent volatiles. These studies will be integrated into a planetarium program that will be hosted at the Watson-King Planetarium, Towson University, and at the University of Missouri, Saint Louis' new digital planetarium, reaching St. Louis and Baltimore students, including many underrepresented minorities. One investigator will also mentor graduate and undergraduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Comets are leftovers from the formation of our solar system some 4.5 billion years ago. Like archaeologists examine artifacts from the ground in order to understand our past, astronomers look to comets in the sky to understand the early history of our solar system. Comets are not pristine, but preserve clues to the processes that occurred when planets were forming and have the potential to help us understand how prebiotically important molecules - those that are needed for life to form - were distributed when our planetary system was very young.

We used telescopic observations and a technique called infrared spectroscopy to decode the composition of ices released from comets as they approach (and are heated by) the Sun and to probe the physical conditions (like varying temperatures) in the expanding atmospheres of these objects. We received time at professional observatories to observe thirteen comets. We sensed a suite of molecules, including prebiotically important ones like water, formaldehyde (a chemical precursor of sugars), ethane and methane (precursors of amines), and hydrogen cyanide and ammonia (precursors of amino acids) and reported our findings in a total of nine refereed journal papers and several scientific conferences. Our findings brought new and important evidence that there are great compositional differences among individual comets in terms of the abundances measured for various volatiles, and in terms of their gas to dust ratios. To understand what this compositional diversity might tell us about the early solar system, we initiated a broad international collaboration between protoplanetary disk modelers and comet scientists. Within this effort, our measurements are being used to further develop protoplanetary disk models to explain how molecules, including those of astrobiological importance, were distributed while planets were forming.

We analyzed short period comet 21P/Giacobini-Zinner and published the first comprehensive catalog of primary volatiles for this comet across three orbits by comparing to results from 1998 and 2005. We securely detected methane and carbon monoxide before, during, and after the comet's closest approach to the Sun (perihelion). We found evidence of variability on short timescales, but the results suggest that formation conditions may dominate processing in setting comet compositions. We also observed comet 2P/Encke, which is the comet with the shortest known orbit (only 3.3 years). We found that the composition of this comet had changed dramatically since it was observed in 2003, several orbits earlier. The cause for this variation is unknown and we have plans to continue our studies of this enigmatic object.  We also collaborated with Dr. Adam McKay on a study of C/2015 R2, which is a comet that had a very unusual composition (dominated by carbon monoxide rather than water, which had never been seen before).

A major component of our program's broader impact was mentoring undergraduate and graduate physics students in all aspects of comet research. During this time, we took advantage of the exceptional remote observing capabilities of the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility. More than 20 students at the University of Missouri - S. Louis were able to participate in our astronomical observing runs over the four years of the award. They took log sheets, controlled the instrument, reduced and analyzed the resulting data, and presented their results at local and regional conferences as well as in a classroom setting. This opportunity gave students valuable experience pertinent to their future careers as scientists.

In addition, PIs Bonev and Gibb both gave numerous public lectures and Gibb participated in the UMSL planetarium outreach program, where middle school students are taught about comets, phases of matter, and the night sky. These programs reach several hundred students in the St. Louis metropolitan region each year, many of whom are from under-represented minorities.
